text: let's go straight to breaking news from
Libya because up to a hundred and fifty
people are feared to have died in a
shipwreck off the Libyan coast there are
reports another 150 people were rescued
and are being taken back to Libya so
let's get the latest from Charlie Axley
who's from UNHCR welcome here to the
program Charlie and UNHCR were the first
to report this so tell me what you know
well we know that a group of around 300
people left from al Homs in Libya their
boat then came into distress and were
rescued by local fishermen and then by
the Libyan Coast Guard who assisted as
well 147 survivors have now been
returned to Libya and we're providing
them with Aid and assistance and they
tell us that they estimate another 150
people died at sea and that figure would
make this the largest shipwreck of 2019
and this tragedy comes just weeks after
we saw more than 50 people died in an
air strike on the Tijera detention
center in Libya so this has to be a
moment now for a change in approach to
the Mediterranean situation in Libya
that sees more search and rescue boats
operating at sea and more than to
release people from these detention
centers saving lives and asked to become
the core priority I'll come back to that
point because I was going to ask you
about it in a moment or two but the
survivors have been taken back
apparently to Libya or our route now
UNHCR was repeatedly said that survivors
should not be taken back to Libya why
not and if not back to Libya then to
where well when people are brought back
to Libya by the Libyan Coast Guard there
they're provided with assistance at the
disembarkation points but afterwards
they're automatically taken to these
detention centers that are run by Libyan
authorities
we know that conditions inside these
centers are appalling there's
insufficient food not in
water the sanitary conditions are very
bad and there's also been testimonies
from people inside these centers of a
range of human rights abuses that they
they endure we have called for many
months for an immediate end to this
system the immediate release of people
inside these detention centers but also
steps taken to prevent people ending up
in there in the first piece yeah just
calling on countries in the region on
both sides of the Mediterranean to come
forward and offer alternative ports of
safety alright just a final question
because you touched on it now MSF have
restarted their rescue boats in the
Mediterranean we now have a new
leadership in Brussels within the EU is
this the moment for a rethink and what
do you think that rethink should
actually take us towards well first of
all we need to see the the role of NGO
boats conducting search and rescue
operations acknowledged they've saved
countless lives at sea in recent years
and their efforts therefore that they
should not be criminalized nor
stigmatized at the same time we need a
return of European state vessels
programs like marine Nostrum were
crucial in preventing loss of life and
the EU must now really consider
returning to search-and-rescue
operations on the Mediterranean well
Charlie actually from UNHCR thanks very
much for joining us live on the program
giving us the latest details on that
developing story thanks so much for your
time
